name: Nuclear Science
overview: Nuclear science gives us a simple explanation of the natural world. The ultimate goal of nuclear science is to find out if there is one fundamental rule that explains how matter and forces interact. Earning the Nuclear Science merit badge is a chance for Scouts to learn about this exciting field at the cutting edge of science today.

content.value: Do the following:
Explain radiation and the difference between ionizing and nonionizing radiation.

resources.title: Radiation & You (video)
IDTIMWYTIM: Radiation (video)

content.value: Explain the ALARA principle. Explain what process you would go through to ensure your dose is kept ALARA when performing the requirements in this merit badge.

resources.title: The ALARA Principle (website)

content.value: Describe the radiation hazard symbol and explain where it should be used.

resources.title: Radiation Hazard Symbol (video)
How Are Universal Ionizing Radiation Symbols Used Around the World? (website)

content.value: Explain how we are exposed to ionizing radiation from outside the earth as well as on earth every day. List four examples of Naturally Occurring Radioactive Materials (NORM) that are in your house or grocery store and explain why they are radioactive.

resources.title: Five Radioactive Products We Use Every Day (video)

content.value: Explain the difference between radiation exposure and contamination. Describe the hazards of radiation to humans, the environment, and wildlife. Calculate your approximate annual radiation dose and compare it to a typical expected dose of someone who works in a nuclear power plant.

resources.title: What Do Radiation Contamination and Exposure Mean? (video)

content.value: Do the following:
Explain the following terms: atom, nucleus, proton, neutron, electron, quark, isotope; alpha particle, beta particle, gamma ray, X-ray; ionization, radioactivity, radioisotope, and stability.

resources.title: Glossary of Nuclear Science Terms (website)
What Are Isotopes? (video)
Quarks Explained (video)

content.value: Choose an element from the periodic table. Construct 3-D models for the atoms of three isotopes of this element, showing neutrons, protons, and electrons. Write down the isotope notation for each model including the atomic and mass numbers. In a separate model or diagram, explain or show how quarks make up protons and neutrons.

resources.title: Make a Model of an Isotope (PDF)
Interactive Isotopes (website)

content.value: Explain how a particle accelerator works.

resources.title: Particle Accelerators: What Are They, How Do They Work and Why Are They Important To Us? (video)

content.value: Do ONE of the following:

resources.title: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory Nuclear Science Division (video)
Inside the World's Largest Science Experiment (video)

content.value: Visit an accelerator, research lab, or university and discuss with a scientist how they study the properties of the nucleus or nucleons.
List three particle accelerators and describe several experiments conducted and their associated basic science and practical applications.
Do TWO of the following:

resources.title: Detecting and Measuring Ionizing Radiation - A Short History (PDF)

content.value: Build an electroscope. Show how it works. Place a radiation source near the electroscope ball and explain the effect it causes.

resources.title: DIY Electroscope (video)

content.value: Make a cloud chamber. Show how it can be used to see the tracks caused by radiation. Explain what is happening.

resources.title: How to Build a Cloud Chamber! (video)
Working Cloud Chamber | Exploratorium (video)
Visualize Radioactive Decay in a Cloud Chamber (PDF)

content.value: Perform an experiment demonstrating half-life. Discuss decay chains.

resources.title: How Radioactive Decay Works | Decay Chains (video)
Skittles Half Life Lab | Radioactive Isotope Decay | Half Life Graph (video)

content.value: Do ONE of the following:

Using a radiation survey meter and a radioactive source, show how the counts per minute change as the source gets closer to or farther from the radiation detector. Place three different materials between the source and the detector, then explain any differences in the measurements per minute. Explain how time, distance, and shielding can reduce an individual's radiation dose.

resources.title: How Materials Shield Radiation (PDF)
Time, Distance and Shielding (video)
Measuring Radiation (video)
Using a Survey Meter: CPM vs Distance (video)

content.value: Describe how radon is detected in homes. Discuss the steps taken for the long-term and short-term test methods, tell how to interpret the results, and explain when each type of test should be used. Explain the health concerns related to radon gas and tell what steps can be taken to reduce radon in buildings.

resources.title: What is Radon, Anyway? (video)
How Dangerous Is Radon to Your Health? (video)

content.value: Visit a place where X-rays are used. Draw a floor plan of this room. Show where the unit, the unit operator, and the patient would be when the X-ray unit is operated. Explain the precautions taken and the importance of those precautions for the safety of the operator.

resources.title: X-Ray Room Tour || Ask the Rad Tech (video)

content.value: Do ONE of the following; then discuss with your counselor how nuclear energy is used to produce electricity:

resources.title: Nuclear Energy (website)

content.value: Make a drawing showing how nuclear fission happens. Observe a mousetrap reactor (setup by an adult) and use it to explain how a chain reaction could be started. Explain how a chain reaction could be stopped or controlled in a nuclear reactor. Explain what is meant by a "critical mass."

resources.title: What Really Happened the First Time We Split a Heavy Atom in Half (video)
What is Critical Mass | Nuclear Chain Reaction| Fission Chain Reaction| Critical Mass Of Uranium (video)
Mousetrap Fission (video)

content.value: Visit a local nuclear power plant or nuclear reactor either in person or online (with your parent or guardian's permission). Learn how a reactor works and how the plant generates electricity. Find out what percentage of electricity in the United States and in your state is generated by nuclear power plants, and by other methods. Make a graph of the information you find.

resources.title: What Is Nuclear Energy? Shrink Down to an Atom and Find Out  (video)
Energy Consumption & Efficiency Data  | Energy Information Agency (website)

content.value: Give an example of each of the following and explain how nuclear science is used in these applications: nuclear medicine, environmental applications, industrial applications, space exploration, and radiation therapy. For each example, explain the application and its significance to nuclear science.

resources.title: Radiation Technologies in Daily Life (video)
Ways Nuclear Science Helps Cancer Patients (video)
Ways Nuclear Techniques Combat Malnutrition (video)
Ways Nuclear Science Helps Ocean Health (video)

content.value: Explore careers related to nuclear science. Research one career to learn about the training and education needed, costs, job prospects, salary, job duties, and career advancement. Your research methods may include—with your parent or guardian's permission—an internet or library search, an interview with a professional in the field, or a visit to a location where people in this career work. Discuss with your counselor both your findings and what about this profession might make it an interesting career.
